name: Moringa Paratha
ingredients: Fresh Moringa leaves (washed and roughly chopped)
instructions: Take wheat flour and add fresh Moringa leaves, roughly chopped, into it.
Add gram flour, finely chopped green chilies, chopped onions, finely chopped ginger, crushed coriander, cumin, salt to taste, and turmeric.
Gradually add water and knead the mixture into a stiff dough.
Add a dash of oil to the dough and knead it well.
Let the dough rest for 10 minutes.
After resting, divide the dough into small pedas (balls).
Take a peda, dust it with dry flour, and roll it out.
Spread a little ghee on the rolled dough, then fold it into a square shape. Roll it again.
Heat a griddle and place the rolled paratha on it.
Apply ghee on both sides as you cook the paratha. Press the sides to ensure it cooks evenly and becomes crispy.
Cook until the paratha is golden and crispy on all sides.
Repeat the process with the remaining dough to prepare all the parathas.

name: Garlic Chutney
instructions: Heat some oil in a pan.
Add garlic and asafoetida for strong flavor.
Add cumin seeds and curry leaves for tempering.
Roast the garlic lightly. Use a small amount of garlic to maintain a balanced flavor.
Add soaked Kashmiri red chili to the pan. This will provide a base and body to the chutney.
Add a little water to adjust consistency.
To balance the spice, add jaggery for sweetness.
For sourness, you can add vinegar or tamarind pulp.
Add salt to taste and cook until the jaggery melts and the water reduces slightly.
Turn off the gas and let the mixture cool down.
Once cooled, grind the mixture to form a smooth chutney.
If you want to increase its shelf life, roast the chutney again after grinding to dry out the water. This will keep the chutney fresh for 7-10 days. Otherwise, consume it within 2-3 days.

name: Tips and Tricks
instructions: Whenever making paratha, always knead a stiff dough for better results.
Let the dough rest for 5-10 minutes after kneading to make it easier to roll.
After dividing the dough into pedas, allow another 5 minutes of rest before rolling them out.
You can use fresh Moringa leaves for paratha or dry them for long-term use.
To dry Moringa leaves, you can use sunlight, shade, or an oven. Store the dried leaves in an airtight container for 4-6 months to retain freshness and nutrients.
Dried Moringa leaves can also be used to make tea. Add the leaves to boiling water, let it rest for 2 minutes, strain, and serve.
Moringa leaves can be added to dals, pulaos, and vegetables to boost nutrition without overpowering the dish's flavor.
Moringa is a superfood rich in nutrients like calcium and Vitamin C. It’s beneficial for immunity, skin, hair, and controlling blood pressure.
